none: F004-04 letter from Paul to Alice: New Orleans, LA (08/14/1895)
F004-04 letter from Paul to Alice: New Orleans, LA (08/14/1895)

services.label: T-PEN Login
services.description: Agreement requires an open T-PEN session to view images

body.value: <note>From: Paul Dunbar To: Alice Ruth Moore New Orleans, La.</note>
Dayton - O. Aug. 14th 1895
Dear Miss Moore: I must confess that to-
night I set down to write to you without knowing what in the
world to say. There is much that I should like to say, much
in my "inner consciousness" that in struggling for expression,
but they are things that to go and must continue to go <unclear>.
From the first that I noticed your work, I was interested
in you more than I dare to say, but now since I have seen
your work I am fairly bewildered. I have read it with
delight, and my appreciation is <unclear> only by my surprise.
I consider your stories pieces of most exquisite art, and it is in them chiefly that I am interested. After reading the
initial story in the book, I wrote involuntarily <unclear> in these words: "it is like one little convulsive heart knot,"
and so to me it is. Your "little Miss Sophie" is as graceful poignant and charming as any thing Grace King ever
wrote. Everything you have written shows remarkable thought and beyond that-talent.
Although I liked your poems-you asked me to be honest-
I was less impressed with them. They are rich in concep-
tion and imagery, but they lack that exactness of form
which is one of my literary hobbies. I hope before
long to be able to review your book where it will
do you some good. If I don't it well be more the fault
of an obdurate editor than mine.
I have just returned from Toledo where I gave a
recital at the State Insane Hospital. I had the
pleasure of recommending your book to friends their
and if selling one copy to a lady who will work to

your interest at Bay View Michigan, where she is also handling the "Woman's Era." Together with payment for my own copy I enclose fifty cents for one to he sent to Mrs. Lottie Jackson, Bay View Michigan. Please send it at once as she can do you good.

I could not understand whether your remark was <unclear> or sarcasm in regard to the review in the Boston Standard. Will you tell me? Also, will you explain you dedication? It puzzles me and forms "a wrote to <unclear> the mind's eye."

I have severed my connection with the Ind. World and I will send your photo home as soon as I can get it from them. My business keeps me traveling a great deal and I find that I can get nothing done properly. At the office when I am away, it is for this season that you have not secured the papers as you should. I am a good deal <unclear> with my little taste of Afro-American (I hate the word) govern-alism

(I hate the word Afro-American, it is a barbaric and clumsy affectation.) But it is heavy and<unclear> and <unclear>, so your educated Negro who by the way loves show, loves the word and rolls it as a sweet morsel over his tongue. But this is a disgression.
I want to know what answer you made to your minister when he asked if you believed in soul affinity. You left me in doubt on that point.
I wish you would send me any little published bit of yours. I am positively hungry for any thing you write.
I hope that you won't think that I am entirely a
fool, but my nature is essentially enthusiastic and
you have greatly roused it. I am sorry that I must-
wait until November for your picture for I am impatient
to have one that is my very own.
I am writing a great deal now and the joy of creat-
ing is in my blood. I know you have felt the same
just as I can appreciate what you experience with the
blues. I am either high on the mountain top or away
down in the valley. Tonight for the first time, I believe, I am sorry that I am not handsome and wealthy-then perhaps I might not have to write a letter that concealed my thoughts!
Sincerely Paul L. Dunbar
